security_audit.summary: Pure utility skill containing only documentation and TypeScript polling utilities. No risk factors detected - no scripts, network calls, filesystem access, environment variable reads, or external command execution.

content.user_title: Eliminate flaky tests with condition polling
content.value_statement: Flaky tests waste time and reduce confidence in your codebase. Condition-based waiting replaces arbitrary timeouts with actual state checks, ensuring tests pass reliably across all environments including CI.
actual_capabilities: Replace arbitrary setTimeout and sleep calls with condition polling
Wait for specific event types to appear in thread managers
Wait for a specific count of events to accumulate
Match events using custom predicate functions
Set configurable timeouts with descriptive error messages
Implement efficient 10ms polling intervals for CPU efficiency
limitations: Does not work for testing actual timing behavior like debounce or throttle
Requires the condition to be checkable via function (not timing-dependent)
Only available for TypeScript and JavaScript testing environments

use_cases.title: Integration test stability
use_cases.description: Ensure database and API integration tests pass consistently without race condition failures

prompt_templates.title: Basic condition check
prompt_templates.prompt: Replace this arbitrary timeout with condition-based waiting: await new Promise(r => setTimeout(r, 100)); expect(element).toBeVisible();

prompt_templates.title: Wait for event
prompt_templates.prompt: Use waitForEvent to wait for a TOOL_RESULT event before asserting on the response data.

prompt_templates.title: Count events
prompt_templates.prompt: Wait for 3 AGENT_MESSAGE events to accumulate using waitForEventCount before validating the conversation flow.

prompt_templates.title: Custom predicate
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a waitForEventMatch call to wait for an event matching (e) => e.type === 'DATA_READY' && e.payload.id === 'item_123'.

output_examples.input: Help me fix this flaky test that randomly fails in CI: await sleep(300); expect(results.length).toBe(5);
output: Replace the arbitrary 300ms sleep with condition polling:
await waitFor(() => results.length === 5, '5 results to be available');
This eliminates timing dependency and ensures the test waits for actual state.

best_practices: Always set reasonable timeout limits (5000ms default) with descriptive error messages
Poll every 10ms for efficiency—1ms wastes CPU, 100ms makes tests slow
Call state getters inside the polling loop, never cache values before it
anti_patterns: Polling too fast (every 1ms) which wastes CPU cycles without benefit
Omitting timeout protection which causes infinite loops if condition never met
Reading state outside the polling loop which captures stale values

faq.question: Which testing frameworks work with this skill?
faq.answer: Any JavaScript or TypeScript testing framework including Jest, Vitest, Mocha, and Playwright.

faq.question: What timeout values work best?
faq.answer: Default 5000ms works for most cases. Increase for slow CI environments or complex async operations.

faq.question: Can this handle cross-tab synchronization?
faq.answer: Yes, poll a shared state variable that both tabs can read and update.

faq.question: Does this modify my test runner?
faq.answer: No, it provides pure utility functions you call from your existing test code.

faq.question: What is the initial polling delay?
faq.answer: First check runs immediately, then every 10ms thereafter.

faq.question: How is this different from @testing-library waitFor?
faq.answer: This provides a lower-level primitive you can adapt to any condition, not just DOM queries.
